paper_title.ja: 樺太アイヌ語の母音の長短と北海道アイヌ語のピッチアクセントとの史的関係(1)-両アイヌ方言の音韻における史的関係の解明に向けての研究序説-
paper_title.en: On the Historical Relationship of the Pitch Accent System of Hokkaido Ainu and the Vowel Length System of Sakhalin Ainu(1) : A Preliminary Study toward the Solution of the Historico-Phonological Relationship of Hokkaido Ainu and Sakhalin Ainu

description.ja: This study is a preliminary research on the historical relationship of the pitch accent system of Hokkaido Ainu and the vowel length system of Sakhalin Ainu. There are two opposing theories on the phonological features of Prote-Ainu, Hatteri Shiro's Vowel Length Theory(1967) and Vovin's Vewel Length and Pitch Accent Theory(l993): Hattori proposed that Proto-Ainu should have a phonological distinction between long and short vowels without pitch accent; on the other hand, Vovin proposed that Proto-Ainu had a phonological distinction not only between long and short vowels but alse between high and low pitch accents. This paper suggests that Proto-Ainu had both vowel length and pitch accent as the phonological features, which supports Vevin's theory.

work_title.en: In search of the origins of Japanese

research_project_title.ja: 言語接触、地域言語学、地理的言語類型論、比較言語学の視点から遺伝学の最先端の研究成果を組み入れた日本語、アイヌ語、朝鮮語の起源・形成についての研究

description.ja:
①東北北部（北奥羽地方）の方言の中に見られる蝦夷語の痕跡は基層か、傍層か、借用か、あるいは単なる空似かを識別し、蝦夷語と東北北部方言との史的関係を明らかにし、現代アイヌ語との関係に迫る。その際、アイヌ人と東北地方の日本人との遺伝学的研究成果も考慮して分析・解明する。
②遺伝学の最先端の研究成果をもとに、日本列島に渡来した人集団の特定とその言語の対応を解き明かすことを試みる。その際、日本列島に渡来する途中経過としてサハリン、韓半島や長江、黄河などの領域の人集団の移動とその言語の移動経路を特定する。時期的には縄文期黎明期から弥生期晩期までを中心にその言語（日本祖語）の特徴を解明する。

research_project_title.en: A Study on the Origins of Japanese, Ainu, Korean on the Basis of Interdisciplinary Approach from the Viewpoint of Linguistics,Genetics,Archeology,and Anthropology

description.en:
1. to pursue the historical relationship of the Northern Tohoku Dialects and the Emishi Language and its descendants of Emishi whose remnants(to be) are found in the Northern Tohoku Dialects
2. to find out the traces of human groups and their langauges who came into the Japanese Archipelago before or after the beginning of the Jomon Era through the Yayoi Era on the Basis of the Most Recent Findings of Genetics, of Archeology, and of Anthropology
